page.title: List of forests managed by the Forestry Commission

revision.text:
The [[Forestry Commission]] manages about one million hectares of land across [[Great Britain]].<ref name=totals>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/AllByUNID/520C1F7C6B16F79C802576A5004CBA16|title=Pamela Warhurst appointed Chair of Forestry Commission|date=8 January 2010|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> The Commission manages 660,000 hectares of forest in Scotland,<ref name=TelegraphQandA>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/agriculture/forestry/8275748/Forest-sell-off-Some-questions-answered.html|title=Forest sell-off: Some questions answered|date=23 January 2011|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> 250,000 hectares in England<ref name=England>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-7RUFP5|title=The Forestry Commission Estate in England|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> and 126,000 hectares in Wales.<ref name=TelegraphQandA /> These forests range from small scale urban forests to many of the largest forests in Britain. The Forestry Commission was set up in 1919 to carry out [[afforestation]] programmes across Britain for timber production. It is also responsible for maintaining and developing recreational facilities within the forests.
==Forests in England== {{expand list|date=July 2012}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- ! scope="col" width="20%" | Name ! scope="col" width="15%" | Location ! scope="col" width="5%" | Size (hectares) ! scope="col" width="55% | Description ! scope="col" width="5%" | References |- |[[Alice Holt Forest]] |[[Hampshire]] |850 |A former [[Royal forest]], Alice Holt is a multi-purpose forest. It is the headquarters for [[Forest Research]] and was the first Research Forest in Britain. |<ref name=AboutAH>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/INFD-6VBEXQ|title=About Alice Holt Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Bedford Purlieus National Nature Reserve|Bedford Purlieus]] |[[Cambridgeshire]] |208 |Bedford Purlieus has been a nature reserve since 2000. It was once part of the [[Rockingham Forest|Royal forest of Rockingham]]. The forest houses a large number of different plants and insect species. |<ref name=BedfordPurlieusNE>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/conservation/designatedareas/nnr/1007635.aspx|title=Bedford Purlieus NNR|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=BedfordPurlieusFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandNorthamptonshireRockinghamForestBedfordPurlieusNationalNatureReserve|title=Bedford Purlieus National Nature Reserve|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Bedgebury National Pinetum|Bedgebury Pinetum]] |[[Kent]] |320 |Bedgebury Pinetum has the largest collection of [[Conifer]]s in the world. It was started in the 1840s and experienced expansion under the control of the Forestry Commission and [[Kew Gardens]] from 1925. The Commission took sole ownership of the Pinetum in 1965. |<ref name=BedgeburyTrees>{{cite web|url=http://www.bedgeburypinetum.org.uk/TheTrees/|title=The Collection|year=2008|accessdate=25 June 2012|publisher=Friends of Bedgebury Pinetum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091105204931/http://www.bedgeburypinetum.org.uk/TheTrees/|archivedate=5 November 2009|df=}}</ref><ref name=BedgeburyFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-6N4FDX|title=History of Bedgebury Pinetum|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Bernwood Forest]] |[[Oxfordshire]] |136 |A former royal hunting forest, Bernwood is a [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] due to its diverse range of butterfly species. |<ref name=OxfordMail>{{cite news|url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/archive/2011/02/11/Oxford+news+%28om_oxfordnews%29/8846183.What_your_MP_thinks_of_forests_plan/|title=What your MP thinks of forests plan|publisher=Oxford Mail|author=Ben Wilkinson|date=11 February 2011|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=BernwoodFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandBuckinghamshireBernwoodForestShabbington|title=Shabbington|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Cannock Chase|Cannock Forest]] |[[Staffordshire]] |2300 |Cannock Forest is within the [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] of [[Cannock Chase]]. The Forestry Commission uses the forest for commercial and recreational purposes. |<ref name=CannockFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/cannockforest|title=Cannock Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=HeritageTrail>{{cite web|url=http://www.cannockchasedc.gov.uk/site/custom_scripts/HeritageTrail/birches_valley.html|title=The Forestry Commission and Cannock Chase|publisher=Cannock Chase Heritage Trail Kiosk|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=CannockNE>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/conservation/designatedareas/aonb/cannock.aspx|title=Cannock Chase|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Cardinham|Cardinham Woods]] |[[Cornwall]] |260 |Cardinham Woods have been managed by the Forestry Commission since 1922. The Commission maintains the woods for commercial purposes and general recreation. |<ref name=CardinhamSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/domesday/dblock/GB-208000-66000/page/11|title=Cardinham Woods,Cardinham |publisher=BBC Domesday Reloaded|year=1986|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=CardinhamFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/Website/recreation.nsf/LUwebdocsBykey/EnglandCornwallNoForestCardinham|title=Cardinham|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Castle Neroche|Neroche Forest]] |[[Somerset]] |1000 |Neroche Forest is within the [[Blackdown Hills]]. The forest is home to [[Castle Neroche]] and one of the Forestry Commission's [[forest school]] projects. |<ref name=NerocheScheme>{{cite web|url=http://www.nerochescheme.org/nerocheProjects.php|title=Neroche projects - Vegetation Monitoring|publisher=Neroche Scheme|year=2007|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=NerocheFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandDevonBlackdownHillsCastleNeroche|title=Castle Neroche|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Dalby Forest]] |[[North Yorkshire]] |3440 |Dalby Forest is within the [[North York Moors]] national park. It is home to several rare insect species. |<ref name=DalbyFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/dalbyforest|title=Dalby Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=DalbySize>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazetteherald.co.uk/news/8967961.Bushcraft_courses_at_Dalby_Forest/|title=Buscraft courses at Dalby Forest|publisher=Gazette & Herald|date=12 April 2011|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=DalbyFly>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/northyorkshire/content/articles/2007/10/01/nob_dalby_forest_feature.shtml|title=Branching out at Dalby Forest|publisher=BBC News|date=22 July 2008|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Delamere Forest]] |[[Cheshire]] |972 |Delamere is the largest forest in Cheshire, though was once part of the larger [[Forests of Mara and Mondrem]]. The [[Sandstone Trail]] passes through the forest. |<ref name=DelamereFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-5K2BU9|title=Information about Delamere|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=SandstoneTrail>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandstonetrail.com/walks-in-delamere-forest/|title=Walks in Delamere Forest|publisher=Walking Cheshire's Sandstone Trail|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Dunwich Forest]] |[[Suffolk]] |270 |Dunwich Forest was primarily a commercial coniferous forest until 2006, when the Forestry Commission and partner organisations began to convert it to mixed woodland and heathland. |<ref name=DunwichSWT>{{cite web|url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves-and-visitor-centres/dunwich-forest/|title=Dunwich Forest|publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=DunwichFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandEastAngliaNoForestDunwichForest|title=Dunwich Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Dymock Woods SSSI|Dymock Woods]] |[[Gloucestershire]] |506 |Dymock Woods contains a Site of Special Scientific Interest and some ancient woodland. |<ref name=DymockFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandHerefordshireHerefordWoodlandsDymockWoods|title=Dymock Woods|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Forest of Bere]] |[[Hampshire]] | |The Forestry Commission manages the remnants of the former royal forest of Bere. The Forest of Bere was one of the forests passed to the Commission upon its establishment in 1919. It has been a major timber forest, providing wood for shipbuilding and resulting in fluctuating forest cover. |<ref name=FarehamBere>{{cite web|url=http://www.fareham.gov.uk/discover_local_area/visiting/where_to_visit/forestofbere.aspx |title=The Forest of Bere |publisher=Fareham Borough Council |accessdate=26 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108184938/http://www.fareham.gov.uk/discover_local_area/visiting/where_to_visit/forestofbere.aspx |archivedate=8 January 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name=BereFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/westwalk|title=Bere - West Walk|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Forest of Dean]] |[[Gloucestershire]] |12000 |The Forest of Dean is an [[ancient forest]]. It contains the largest number of ancient oak trees anywhere in Britain. |<ref name=DeanSize>{{cite web|url=http://rdpenetwork.defra.gov.uk/funding-sources/local-action-groups/forest-of-dean|title=Forest of Dean|publisher=Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=DeanFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestofdean|title=Forest of Dean|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Friston Forest]] |[[East Sussex]] |850 |Friston Forest contains many walking and cycling routes. It is in the [[South Downs]] and is home to some rare butterflies. |<ref name=FristonSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/WebNewsReleases/AFA629346C092F728025779D003AE1CD|title=Future Landscape Conference visits Sussex|date=14 September 2010|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=FristonFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fristonforest|title=Friston Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Grizedale Forest]] |[[Cumbria]] |2447 |Grizedale Forest is within the [[Lake District National Park]], near [[Windermere]]. The forest is mainly recreational, with several biking trails and waymarked paths. |<ref name=GrizedaleSize>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/agriculture/forestry/8276046/Sale-of-Rigg-Wood-could-herald-forests-future.html|title=Sale of Rigg Wood could herald forests' future |author=Rebecca Lefort|date=23 January 2011|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=26}}</ref><ref name=GrizedaleFC>{{cite web|url=http://visitlakelandforests.co.uk/index.php/your-forests/grizedale/overview|title=Grizedale - Wild about the forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Guisborough Forest]] |[[North Yorkshire]] |468 |Guisborough Forest is within the boundaries of the [[North York Moors]]. |<ref name=GuisboroughSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/WebNewsReleases/0AEEB59493A66FD08025723700338665|title=MOTHER NATURE GOES BACK TO WORK IN GUISBOROUGH FOREST|date=8 December 2006|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=GuisboroughFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/guisborough|title=Guisborough Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Haldon Forest]] |[[Devon]] |3500 |Haldon Forest Park provides a habitat for over 30 butterfly species and many birds of prey. The Forestry Commission maintains several walking an cycling trails across the forest. |<ref name=HaldonFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/haldonforestpark|title=Haldon Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=SaveHaldon>{{cite web|url=http://www.eclipse.co.uk/exeter/haldon/|title=Save Haldon Forest|date=February 2011|publisher=Save Haldon Forest group|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Hamsterley Forest]] |[[County Durham]] |2000 |The Forestry Commission claims that Hamsterley Forest is one of the most popular attractions in County Durham. The Forest has a large number of cycling and walking trails. |<ref name=HamsterleyRun>{{cite web|url=http://www.butterwick.org.uk/whatyoucando/fundraising/event_pages/hamsterley10k|title=Hamsterley Forest 10k|publisher=Butterwick Hospice|year=2012|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=HamsterleyFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/hamsterleyforest|title=Hamsterley Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=MostPopular>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-8SRFE5|title=Hamsterley Development Project|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Kesteven Forest]] |[[Lincolnshire]] | |Kesteven Forest covers several woods, including the [[Bourne Woods]]. |<ref name=KestevenFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/kestevenforest|title=Kesteven Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Kielder Forest]] |[[Northumberland]] |65000 |Kielder is the largest artificial forest in England and remains one of the Forestry Commission's major timber producing forests. The forest has been under the management of the Commission since it was planted in the 1920s. |<ref name=KielderFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/Recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandNorthumberlandKielder|title=Kielder|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=KielderTrust>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitkielder.com/about-us|title=Information about the Kielder Partnership|publisher=Kielder Water & Forest Park Development Trust|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Mortimer Forest]] |[[Shropshire]] |1029 |Mortimer Forest originally provided firewood for [[Ludlow Castle]]. It now contains several biking trails and walking routes as well as a permanent [[orienteering]] course. |<ref name=MortimerSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/web-allbysubject/AD8ACADDCA6E439980256D800033BD46|title=DEBATE ON MORTIMER'S MEDIEVAL FUTURE|date=12 August 2003|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=MortimerFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandHerefordshireTheMarchesMortimerForest|title=Mortimer Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[New Forest]] |[[Hampshire]] |37677 |The New Forest is an ancient forest that was planted around 1000 CE. Much of the forest has been within the [[New Forest National Park]] since 2005. |<ref name=NewForestFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/forestry.nsf/byunique/infd-69vhwv|title=About the New Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=NewForestNE>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/about_us/news/2010/170310.aspx|title=New Forest to benefit from landmark conservation agreement|date=17 March 2010|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Parkhurst Forest]] |[[Isle of Wight]] |395 |Parkhurst Forest is one of the oldest forests in England. It is home to rare plant and tree species as well as some less common insects. |<ref name=ParkhurstDesign>{{cite document|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/pdf/see-parkhurst-forest.pdf/$FILE/see-parkhurst-forest.pdf|title=Parkhurst Forest design plan|page=154–178|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=ParkhurstFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/Recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandIsleofWightTheForestsoftheIsleofWightParkhurstForest|title=Parkhurst Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Queen Elizabeth Country Park]] |[[Hampshire]] |570 |Queen Elizabeth Country Park lies within the [[South Downs]]. It is managed by the Forestry Commission on behalf of [[Hampshire County Council]]. |<ref name=QueenLizSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.environmentcentre.com/rte.asp?id=179|title=Queen Elizabeth Country Park Woodchip-fired biomass boiler heating system|publisher=Sustainable planning and purchase centre|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Rendlesham Forest]] |[[Suffolk]] |1500 |Rendlesham Forest is best known for the [[Rendlesham Forest Incident]]. This incident provided the inspiration for the UFO themed recreational facilities. |<ref name=RendleshamFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandEastAngliaNoForestRendleshamWood|title=Rendlesham Wood|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=RendleshamForestCentre>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/rendlesham|title=Rendlesham Forest Centre|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Rockingham Forest]] |[[Northamptonshire]] | |Rockingham Forest was a royal hunting forest. The Commission originally expanded the forest using fast growing conifers, but has begun a project to convert much of this to mixed woodland. |<ref name=RockinghamFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/rockinghamforest|title=Rockingham Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=RockinghamTrust>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockingham-forest-trust.org.uk/theforest.html|title=Rockingham Forest - The Forest|publisher=Rockingham Forest Trust|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Salcey Forest]] |[[Northamptonshire]] |495 |Salcey Forest has a 20 metre high "Tree Top Walkway". The forest is also made up of ancient woodland including 600-year-old oak trees. |<ref name=SalceyFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandNorthamptonshireNoForestSalceyForest|title=Salcey Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=SalceySize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/WebNewsReleases/E5C160DEF5F1154B802575BA002E8C31|title=Green light for forest makeover|date=18 May 2009|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=SalceyOaks>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/infd-8lvegp|title=Wildlife and Environment|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Savernake Forest]] |[[Wiltshire]] |1100 |Savernake Forest is privately owned and has been managed by the Forestry Commission since 1939 on a 999-year lease. The Commission has logging rights and operates a campsite within the forest. |<ref name=SavernakeFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandWiltshireMarlboroughWoodlandsSavernake|title=Savernake|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=Savernake999>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/AllByUNID/52D3F51BCEDB04D0802572FB004D682E|title=CAN'T SEE THE TREES FOR THE WOOD|publisher=Forestry Commission|date=27 June 2007|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Sherwood Forest]] |[[Nottinghamshire]] |1340 |Sherwood Forest is an ancient forest known for its connections with [[Robin Hood]]. It is a former royal hunting forest that is mostly managed by the Forestry Commission. |<ref name=SherwoodHistory>{{cite web|url=http://www.sherwoodforest.info/4653.html|title=History of Sherwood|publisher=Sherwoodforest.info|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=SherwoodPinesFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandNottinghamshireNoForestSherwoodPinesForestPark|title=Sherwood Pines Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Sherwood Pines Forest Park|Sherwood Pines]] |[[Nottinghamshire]] |1925 |The forestry commission obtained a 999 year lease in 1925. The forest also has a visitor centre and forest activities. |<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sherwoodforestvisitor.com/2012/10/18/sherwood-forest-clipstone-heath/|title=Sherwood Pines – Clipstone Forest|date=18 October 2012|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forestry.gov.uk/sherwoodpines|title=Sherwood Pines|first=Forestry Commission,|last=England|website=www.forestry.gov.uk}}</ref> |- |[[Thetford Forest]] |[[East Anglia]] |19000 |Thetford Forest was created by the Forestry Commission in 1922 for commercial logging. Recreational facilities, such as waymarked paths and cycle trails have been developed since. |<ref name=ThetfordSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/naturescalendar/spring/woods_gen/thetford/thetford.shtml|title=Thetford Forest - Modern forest|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=ThetfordFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/thetfordforestpark|title=Thetford Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Wendover Woods]] |[[Buckinghamshire]] |325 |Wendover Woods are on the [[Chiltern Hills]]. The woods are made up of a mixture of coniferous and broad leafed trees. |<ref name=WendoverFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandBuckinghamshireNoForestWendoverWoods|title=Wendover Woods|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Westonbirt Arboretum]] |[[Gloucestershire]] |250 |The Westonbirt Arboretum was established in 1829 and given to the Forestry Commission in 1956. The arboretum contains approximately 16000 trees from around the world. |<ref name=WestonbirtFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/forestry.nsf/byunique/infd-8j9ce8|title=About Westonbirt, The National Arboretum|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=WestonbirtHistory>{{cite web|url=http://www.fowa.org.uk/who_we_are/our_history|title=Friends of Westonbirt Arboretum - Our History|publisher=Friends of Westonbirt Arboretum|accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Whinlatter|Whinlatter Forest]] |[[Cumbria]] |1226 |The Forestry Commission claims that Whinlatter Forest is "the only true Mountain Forest" in England. The forest is 790 metres above sea level and is located within the [[Lake District National Park]]. It has been mostly used as a recreational forest since 1965. |<ref name=WhinlatterFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/EnglandCumbriaNoForestWhinlatterForestParkWhinlatterVisitorCentre|title=Whinlatter Visitor Centre|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=WhinlatterSize>{{cite document|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/pdf/englandnwefdwhinlatterfdptext.pdf/$FILE/englandnwefdwhinlatterfdptext.pdf|title=Whinlatter Forest Design Plan|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Wyre Forest]] |[[Worcestershire]] / [[Shropshire]] |2600 |Wyre Forest is among the largest of Britain's ancient forests. Large parts of the forest are within a Site of Special Scientific Interest. |<ref name=WyreSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-76KD2G|title=20 Questions & Answers to put you in the picture|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=WyreFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/wyreforest|title=Wyre Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref> |}
==Forests in Scotland== {{expand list|date=July 2012}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- ! scope="col" width="20%" | Name ! scope="col" width="15%" | Location ! scope="col" width="5%" | Size (hectares) ! scope="col" width="55% | Description ! scope="col" width="5%" | References |- |[[Achnashellach Forest]] |[[Scottish Highlands]] | |Achnashellach Forest does not have recreational facilities that many other Forestry Commission forests have. It is in a remote part of the Scottish Highlands and is fairly mountainous. The Forest was originally part of a [[Caledonian Forest]]. |<ref name=AchnashellachFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/ScotlandHighlandNoForestAchnashellachNorth|title=Achnashellach (North)|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=AchnashellachCP>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/ScotlandHighlandNoForestAchnashellachNorthAchnashellachCarpark|title=Achnashellach Car Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Argyll Forest Park]] |[[Argyll and Bute]] |24,281 |In 1935, Argyll Forest became the first Forest Park in Britain. It lies on the border between the [[Scottish Highlands]] and the [[Scottish Lowlands]]. |<ref name=ArgyllFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/argyllforestpark|title=Argyll Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=VisitCowal>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitcowal.co.uk/argyll-forest-park.html|title=Argyll Forest Park|publisher=Visit Cowal|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=ArgyllSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottish-places.info/features/featurefirst7808.html|title=Overview of Argyll Forest Park|publisher=The editors of the Gazetteer for Scotland|year=2011|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Craik Forest]] |[[Scottish Borders]] | |Craik Forest is primarily a commercial forest with timber being processed at facilities nearby. There are some recreational facilities within the forest. |<ref name=CraikFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/ScotlandScottishBordersForestsoftheScottishBordersCraik|title=Craik|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=CraikCommercial>{{cite news|url=http://www.dumgal.gov.uk/index.aspx?articleid=4182&item=4871|title=Craik Forest project receives funding to improve timber haulage |date=2 October 2009|publisher=Dumfries and Galloway Council|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Dalbeattie Forest]] |[[Dumfries and Galloway]] |1100 |Dalbeattie Forest has primarily been a commercial forest, though the Forestry Commission has worked with local organisations to expand recreational facilities. The forest now hosts one of the [[7stanes]] biking trails. |<ref name=DalbeattieSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.dalbeattiematters.co.uk/features.asp?ID=114|title=Introduction to the Partnership|publisher=Dalbeattie Community Council & Dalbeattie Community Initiative|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=DalbeattieFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/ScotlandDumfriesshireForestsoftheSolwayCoastDalbeattieForest|title=Dalbeattie Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Forest of Ae]] |[[Dumfries and Galloway]] |9100 |Ae was created by the Forestry Commission soon after it was established. While it is mainly a commercial forest, it is also one of the 7stanes forests. |<ref name=AeSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/WebPressReleases/38647C3B46D1121580256CB500483F97|title=Ae windfarm proposal|publisher=Forestry Commission|date=27 January 2003|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=AeFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUwebdocsBykey/ScotlandDumfriesshireForestsoftheSouthernUplandsForestofAe|title=Forest of Ae|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Galloway Forest Park]] |[[Dumfries and Galloway]] |97000 |Galloway Forest is the largest forest in Britain. In 2009 it became the first Dark Sky Park in the UK. |<ref name=GallowaySize>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-south-scotland-18076531|title=Galloway Forest Park project seeks business interests|publisher=BBC News|date=16 May 2012|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=GallowayFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/gallowayforestpark|title=Galloway Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=DarkSky>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/south_of_scotland/8361244.stm|title=Forest park given Dark Sky honour |date=16 November 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Garscadden Wood]] |[[Glasgow]] |16.94 |Garscadden Wood lies within the [[Drumchapel Woodlands]], slightly north west of Glasgow. |<ref name=GarscaddenFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/ScotlandCityofGlasgowDrumchapelWoodlandsGarscaddenWoodWest|title=Garscadden Wood West|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=GarscaddenSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.glasgow.gov.uk/en/Residents/Parks_Outdoors/Ecology/Wildlife_Sites/garscaddenwood.htm|title=Garscadden Wood|publisher=Living in Glasgow|date=24 August 2009|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Glen Affric]] |[[Highland (council area)|Highland]] |9000 |Glen Affric is home to a large area of [[Caledonian Forest]] and is designated a [[National Nature Reserves in Scotland|National Nature Reserve]]. |<ref name=AffricFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/forestry.nsf/byunique/infd-89yjpf|title=Trees are the glory of Glen Affric|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=AffricSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.caledonia.org.uk/socialland/affric.htm|title=The AGREEMENT between FORESTRY ENTERPRISE and TREES FOR LIFE on work in the GLEN AFFRIC CALEDONIAN FOREST RESERVE|publisher=Caledonian Centre for Social Development|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Glencoe Lochan]] |[[Highland (council area)|Highland]] | |Glencoe Lochan forest was established by [[Donald Smith, 1st Baron Strathcona and Mount Royal|1st Baron Strathcona]] in the 19th century. It is a coniferous forest. |<ref name=GlencoeFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUwebdocsBykey/ScotlandHighlandGlencoeGlencoeLochan|title=Glencoe Lochan|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Glenmore Forest Park]] |[[Highland (council area)|Highland]] |3500 |Genmore contains some caledoninan woodland. It became the second Forest Park to be created by the Commission in 1948. |<ref name=GlenmoreFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/glenmoreforestpark|title=Glenmore Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=GlenmoreSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.rspb.org.uk/media/releases/details.aspx?id=tcm:9-182515|title=Unique woodland conservation scheme helps black grouse recovery|publisher=Royal Society for Protection of Birds|author=James Reynolds|date=30 January 2008|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Knapdale Forest]] |[[Argyll and Bute]] |19800 |Knapdale has a colony of beavers as part of the Scottish Beaver Trial. |<ref name=Knapdale>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/ScotlandArgyllandButeNoForestKnapdaleForest|title=Knapdale Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=KnapdaleBeavers>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishbeavers.org.uk/visit-knapdale/|title=Visit Knapdale|publisher=Scottish Wildlife Trust|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=KnapdaleSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.wildaboutbritain.co.uk/knapdale-forest|title=Knapdale Forest|publisher=Wild about Britain|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Mabie, Dumfries and Galloway|Mabie Forest]] |[[Dumfries and Galloway]] | |Mabie Forest has been owned by the Forestry Commission since 1943. It has become a recreational forest, with walking routes and 7stanes biking trails. |<ref name=MabieFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUwebdocsBykey/ScotlandDumfriesshireForestsoftheSolwayCoastMabieForest|title=Mabie Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Queen Elizabeth Forest Park]] |[[Stirling (council area)|Stirling]] |16780 |The Queen Elizabeth Forest Park consists of several forests. It became a forest park in 1953 as part of the coronation of [[Queen Elizabeth II]]. |<ref name=QEFPSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottish-places.info/features/featurefirst7724.html|title=Queen Elizabeth Forest Park|publisher=Gazetteer for Scotland|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=QEFPFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/qefp|title=Queen Elizabeth Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Tay Forest Park]] |[[Perthshire]] | |The Tay Forest Park is made up of several different forests. The forest has been visited by several royals, including [[Queen Victoria]] and [[Queen Isabella of Scotland]]. |<ref name=TayFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/tayforestpark|title=Tay Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Tweed Valley Forest Park]] |[[Scottish Borders]] |6800 |The Tweed Valley Forest Park is made up of seven forests around the Scottish Borders. [[Glentress Forest|Glentress]] and [[Innerleithen Forest|Innerleithen]] forests are part of the 7stanes biking trail project. |<ref name=TweedSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/AllByUNID/9BF2F346C296605C80256DBE0048597E|title=New Forest Park Seeks Friends|publisher=Forestry Commission|date=13 October 2003|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=TweedFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/TVFP|title=Welcome to Tweed Valley Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> |}
==Forests in Wales== {{expand list|date=July 2012}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- ! scope="col" width="20%" | Name ! scope="col" width="15%" | Location ! scope="col" width="5%" | Size (hectares) ! scope="col" width="55% | Description ! scope="col" width="5%" | References |- |[[Afan Forest Park]] |[[Neath Port Talbot]] |11000 |Afan Forest Park covers the [[Afan Valley]] and the surrounding area. The forest park contains several long distance cycle routes. |<ref name=AfanFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/WalesNeathPortTalbotAfanForestParkAfanForestPark|title=Afan Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Beddgelert Forest]] |[[Snowdonia]] |700 | |<ref name=BeddglertFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUwebDocsByKey/WalesGwyneddBeddgelertBeddgelertForest|title=Beddgelert Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Brechfa Forest]] |[[Carmarthenshire]] |6500 |Brechfa Forest has been a mixed commercial and recreational forest since it was placed under the management of the Forestry Commission in 1919. The forest contains ancient woodland and was a royal hunting forest. |<ref name=BrechfaFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUwebdocsBykey/WalesCarmarthenshireNoForestBrechfa|title=Brechfa|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=VisitBrechfa>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitbrechfaforest.com/|title=Brechfa Forest|publisher=Brechfa Forest Carmarthenshire|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Coed-y-Brenin]] |[[Snowdonia]] |3600 |Coed-y-Brenin has several mountain bike trails and has hosted races since 1991. |<ref name=BreninFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-8BGRDE|title=Welcome to Coed y Brenin Forest Park|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=BreninSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/wales/north-wales/dolgellau/activities/mountain-biking/coed-brenin-forest|title=Coed y Brenin Forest Park|publisher=Lonely Planet|accessdate=2 July}}</ref> |- |[[Cwmcarn Forest]] |[[Caerphilly County Borough|Caerphilly]] |1200 |The Forestry Commission created Cwmcarn Forest in 1922 over a former [[colliery]]. |<ref name=CwmcarnFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/WalesCaerphillyCwmcarnForestCwmcarnForest|title=Cwmcarn Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=CwmcarnSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/AllByUNID/B86F2F9C53EBE2F6802578550035595A|title=Cwmcarn earns its stripes in rock band video|date=18 March 2011|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=CwmcarnHistory>{{cite web|url=http://your.caerphilly.gov.uk/cwmcarnforest/history/history|title=History of Cwmcarn Forest|publisher=fforest Cwmcarn Forest|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Dyfnant Forest]] |[[Powys]] |2430 |Dyfnant Forest has five horse riding trails, known as the "rainbow trails". |<ref name=DyfnantFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/WalesPowysDyfnant|title=Dyfnant|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Fforest Fawr]] |[[Powys]] | |Fforest Fawr was the first [[Geopark]] in Wales. It lies within the [[Brecon Beacons National Park]]. |<ref name=FawrFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestfawr|title=Fforest Fwar|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=FawrGeopark>{{cite web|url=http://www.fforestfawrgeopark.org.uk/|title=Welcome to the Fforest Fawr Geopark|publisher=Fforest Fawr Geopark|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Glasfynydd Forest]] |[[Carmarthenshire]] / [[Powys]] | |Glasfynydd Forest surrounds the [[Usk Reservoir]] and is mainly a coniferous forest. |<ref name=GlasfynyddFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUwebDocsByKey/WalesMerthyrTydfilBreconBeaconsNationalParkForestsGlasfynydd|title=Glasfynnyd|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Gwydir Forest]] |[[Snowdonia]] |7250 |Gwydir Forest is one of several forests that the Commission planted across Welsh Mining areas. Gwydir now has several recreational facilities including walking and cycling routes. |<ref name=GwydirFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/gwydyrforestpark|title=Gwydyr|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Hafren Forest]] |[[Powys]] |13000 |The forest is named after the [[River Severn]] (Afron Hafren) as the river rises close to the forest border. The Forestry Commission planted the forest in 1937 as a source of timber. |<ref name=HafrenSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/newsrele.nsf/AllByUNID/F7F8743BCEA6906C80257930002DAF72|title=From the family farm to the forests of mid-Wales|date=31 October 2011|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=HafrenFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/WalesPowysHafren|title=Hafren|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Hiraethog Forest]] |[[Denbighshire]] |6000 |Hiraethog Forest is a large commercial pine forest in North Wales. Recreational facilities and [[Red Squirrel]]s lie within [[Clocaenog Forest]]. |<ref name=HiraethogFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUwebDocsByKey/WalesDenbighshireHiraethogForest|title=Hiraethog Forest|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Newborough Forest]] |[[Anglesey]] |700 |The Forestry Commission planted Newborough Forest in 1947 as part of its post-war afforestation efforts. It was primarily to stabilise the sand dunes near [[Newborough, Anglesey|Newborough]]. |<ref name=NewboroughFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/wildwoods.nsf/LUwebDocsByKey/WalesIsleofAngleseyNoForestNewborough|title=Newborough|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=NewboroughSize>{{cite web|url=http://www.savenewboroughforest.org.uk/More.htm|title=Why Save Newborough Forest?|publisher=Save Newborough Forest|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Radnor Forest]] |[[Powys]] |1500 |Radnor Forest is mostly a commercial coniferous forest managed by the Forestry Commission. It has some waymarked footpaths and access for horse riding. |<ref name=RadnorSize>{{cite web|url=http://gothisplace.com/View/English/Radnor%20Forest,%20UK|title=Radnor Forest |publisher=Go this place|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=RadnorFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUWebDocsByKey/WalesPowysRadnorRadnorWood|title=Radnor Wood|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |- |[[Wentwood]] |[[Newport, Wales|Newport]] / [[Monmouthshire]] | |Wentwood is managed by several organisations, with the Forestry Commission carrying out commercial forestry operations in much of the Forest. The forest is an ancient forest, with much of the area replanted by the Commission with conifers. |<ref name=WentwoodFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/website/recreation.nsf/LUwebDocsByKey/WalesMonmouthshireNoForestWentwood|title=Wentwood|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=WentwoodWT>{{cite web|url=http://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/en/our-woods/Pages/about-this-wood.aspx?wood=5581#.T_F29XBSGi4|title=Wentwood: About this wood|publisher=Woodland Trust|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> |}

<!--PLEASE add all images to the top section of this article--> [[Image:JC Nichols Fountain by Henri-Léon Gréber Kansas City.jpg|thumb|290px|right|''J.C. Nichols Memorial Fountain'', by [[Henri-Léon Gréber]] (1910, reinstalled in Kansas City and dedicated in 1960) at 47th Street and J.C. Nichols Parkway, [[Country Club Plaza]].]] [[Image:VMuse of the Missouri.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Muse of the Missouri'', by [[Wheeler Williams]], downtown, Main Street at 9th Street.]] [[Image:Henry Wollman Bloch Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Henry Wollman Bloch Fountain'', in front of Union Station, at W. Pershing Road at Main Street.]] [[Image:VChildrens Fountain.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Children's Fountain'', by Tom Corbin, at Oak Trafficway & Burlington (MO Hwy 9).]] [[Image:Volker Fountain Waterfall Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Volker Fountain'', {{convert|28|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} waterfall and basin along Brush Creek, Volker Boulevard, between Oak St. and Rockhill Road.]] [[Image:Double Monopole KCI Airport.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Double Monopole'', by Keith Sonnier; twin {{convert|60|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} waterfall sculptures lighted by red, blue, and yellow neon lights, in the median of Cookingham Drive at Paris Street, at [[Kansas City International Airport]].]] [[Image:Fountain of Bacchus Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Fountain of Bacchus'', W. 47th Street at Chandler Court in The Plaza. The main sculpture is made of {{convert|10000|lb|abbr=on}} of cast lead.]] [[Image:Firefighters Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Firefighters' Fountain'', W. 31st Street and Broadway.]] [[Image:Pomona Fountain by Donatello Gabbrielli Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Pomona'', fountain sculpture by Donatello Gabbrielli, at Ward Parkway & Broadway, in The Plaza.]] [[Image:Northland Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Northland Fountain'', at Oak Trafficway & Vivion Road.]] [[Image:Eagle Scout Memorial Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Eagle Scout Memorial Fountain'', E. 39th Street at Gillham Road.]] [[Image:Crowncenterfountain.JPG|thumb|180px|right|''Crown Center Square Fountain'' at [[Crown Center]], Grand Avenue & E. Pershing during the holidays.]] [[Image:Crown Center Square Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Crown Center Square Fountain''. "Dancing Waters" shows with synchronized {{convert|60|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} jets of water run every hour all day on weekends, and at noon & evening hours on weekdays.]] [[Image:Meyer Circle Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Meyer Circle ("Seahorse") Fountain'', at Meyer Boulevard & Ward Parkway. The fountain hosts a 17th-century Venetian sculpture.]] [[Image:Kauffmanstad.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Waterworks Spectacular'', at Kauffman Stadium.]] [[Image:Fountains in Brush Creek Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Fountains in Brush Creek, along Ward Parkway, in The Plaza.]] [[Image:Sea Sirens Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Mermaid Fountain'', at Nichols Road & Broadway, in The Plaza.]] [[Image:Fountain at Liberty Memorial Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|A fountain at [[Liberty Memorial]].]] [[Image:Kansas City Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fountain.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Kansas City Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fountain'', at Broadway & W. 41st Street, in Westport.]] [[Image:Neptune Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Neptune Fountain'', W. 47th Street & Wornall Road, in The Plaza.]] [[Image:Northeast Concourse Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Northeast Concourse Fountain'', on St. John Avenue between Gladstone and Benton Boulevards.]] [[Image:Diana and Cherubs Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Diana (and Cherubs)'', fountain sculpture, at Ward Parkway & Wornall Road, in The Plaza.]] [[Image:Car Fountain Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Auto dealership "car fountain", on NW Prairie View Drive, at I-29.]]
This page contains a '''list of fountains in Kansas City''' metropolitan area. It is primarily composed of [[fountain]]s in [[Kansas City, Missouri]] officially recognized by the City of Fountains Foundation,<ref>[http://www.kcfountains.org/news/index.html City of Fountains | News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> but also includes fountains throughout the [[Kansas City Metropolitan Area]].
In 1992, the city added "City of Fountains" to its official corporate seal.<ref name="ordinance">[http://cityclerk.kcmo.org/liveweb/Documents/Document.aspx?q=xM%2blSxLerCNiQrj6QKGv5YDbX73DmbugafyFKfnWxR15N%2bcusJphzeai9HojEx1K 1992 ordinance enacting new logo]</ref>
==Description== Fountains form part of the Kansas City's core identity and culture, and it even used a graphic design of a stylized fountain in its official logo.<ref name="ordinance" /> Interest in fountains arose during the [[City Beautiful movement]] in the 1890s. In 1898, [[George Kessler]], a landscape architect and urban planner, designed the first fountain built by the city of Kansas City, Missouri at 15th and [[The Paseo]]. Although it was destroyed in 1941, another fountain that he designed the same year still exists and remains the oldest in the city. Now known as '''''The Women's Leadership Fountain''''', it is located at 9th Street and The Paseo. The design originally included an oval, cut limestone basin with water spraying upwards from nozzles in the center of the its pool surrounded by a raised sidewalk, a flower garden, gas lamps, and a balustrade above to the south.<ref name="kcfountains.org">[http://www.kcfountains.org/education/history.htm City of Fountains Foundation (KCFountains.org), ''Education: Brief History of Kansas City Fountains''], downloaded 3 August 2008</ref> The fountain was rebuilt in 1970 and 1990 and began its third major restoration in January 2008 planned for completion in 2009.<ref>The Kansas City Star, ''KC's oldest fountain is undergoing renovation'', 10 March 2009, p. F4</ref> Kessler went on to include numerous plans for fountains in his urban designs of the park and boulevard system.
Typically, most of the first fountains in Kansas City served practical rather than decorative purposes. In 1904, the Humane Society of Kansas City (Kansas) – established to prevent cruelty to women, children and animals – built a characteristic fountain near the west end of Minnesota Avenue at North 3rd Street. Water poured out of spigots in lions' mouths so that people could get clean water in their cups. This water fell into a granite basin at a height for horses to drink. The overflow from the basin went into four small pools at street level for dogs to drink. A street light was on top; in 1967, the fountain was given to the Wyandotte County Museum. The Humane Society went on to mount more than 100 fountains, including ones made of bronze created for people alone for sanitary purposes.<ref name="kcfountains.org"/>
Fountain building and the use of decorative statuary exploded in the 1920s after developer [[J.C. Nichols]] used them extensively in the development of [[Country Club Plaza]]. The most famous fountain in Kansas City is appropriately named '''''J.C. Nichols Memorial Fountain'''''. The figures were originally created by French sculptor [[Henri-Léon Gréber]] in 1910 for "Harbor Hill," the estate of [[Clarence Mackay]] in [[Roslyn, New York]]. The four allegorical [[equestrianism|equestrian]] figures reportedly represent four great rivers of the world — the [[Mississippi River]], [[Volga River]], [[Seine River]], and [[Rhine River]].<ref>[http://www.mackayhistory.com/JCNicholsFountain.html MacKayHistory.com, ''Mackay Fountain, 1910 to c.1949''], downloaded 21 July 2008.</ref> The work is enlivened by sculptures of little children riding dolphins in the pool surrounding the main figures.
The ''William Volker Memorial Fountain'' includes the last sculptures by Swedish artist [[Carl Milles]]. The five-piece ensemble of bronze statuary shows [[Martin of Tours|Saint Martin of Tours]], [[patron saint]] of [[France]], on horseback, giving his clothes to a [[beggar]] surrounded by two [[angel]]s (one amusingly wearing a [[wristwatch]]) and a curious little [[demon]] in hiding. The sculptures rest between two pools of water with jet sprays along Volker Boulevard, and sits above a dramatic three-tier, {{convert|28|ft|m|abbr=on}} waterfall into a basin on Brush Creek.<ref>[http://www.kcfountains.org/find_fountain/displayfountain.asp?FID=25 City of Fountains Foundation (KCFountains.org), ''Volker Memorial Fountain''], downloaded 3 August 2008.</ref>
The ''Eagle Scout Memorial Fountain'' was originally part of the [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh Avenue]] clock created by [[Adolph Alexander Weinman|A.A. Weinman]] for the [[Pennsylvania Station (1910–1963)|Pennsylvania Station]] in [[New York City]]. When the station was torn down, Kansas City petitioned to obtain the clock sculpture and replaced its face with an [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]] tribute.
The "Waterworks Spectacular" has been dousing the outfield during [[baseball]] games at [[Kauffman Stadium]] for over 30 years.

revision.text:
This article is a '''list of diseases''' of [[Mentha|mint]] (''Mentha piperita'', ''M. cardiaca'', ''M. spicata'' and ''M. arvensis''). ==Fungal diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Fungal diseases'''
|- |Anthracnose || ''[[Sphaceloma menthae]]'' |- |Black stem rot || ''[[Phoma strasseri]]'' |- |Leaf blight || ''[[Cephalosporium]]'' sp. |- |Phoma leaf spot || ''[[Phoma exigua]]'' |- |Powdery mildew || ''[[Erysiphe]]'' spp.
''[[Erysiphe cichoracearum]]'' |- |Ramularia leaf spot || ''[[Ramularia menthicola]]'' |- |Rust || ''[[Puccinia menthae]]''
''[[Puccinia angustata]]'' |- |Septoria leaf spot || ''[[Septoria menthae]]'' |- |Stem and stolon canker || ''[[Rhizoctonia solani]]''
''[[Thanatephorus cucumeris]]''[teleomorph] |- |Stolon decay || ''[[Fusarium solani]]''
''[[Nectria haematococca]]'' [teleomorph] |- |Verticillium wilt || ''[[Verticillium albo-atrum]]''
''[[Verticillium albo-atrum var. menthae]]''
''[[Verticillium dahliae]]'' |- |White mold stem rot || ''[[Sclerotinia sclerotiorum]]'' |- |} ==Nematodes, parasitic== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Nematodes, parasitic'''
|- |Leaf & bud || ''[[Aphelenchoides parietinus]]'' |- |Lesion || ''[[Pratylenchus neglectus]]''
''[[Pratylenchus penetrans]]'' |- |Needle || ''[[Longidorus elongatus]]''
''[[Longidorus sylphus]]'' |- |Pin || ''[[Paratylenchus hamatus]]''
''[[Paratylenchus microdorus]]''
{{=}} ''[[Paratylenchus macrophallus]]'' |- |Root-knot || ''[[Meloidogyne hapla]]'' |- |} ==Viral diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Viral diseases'''
|- |Spotted wilt ||[[Tomato spotted wilt virus]] |- |} == References == {{reflist}} *{{cite web|last1=Green|first1=R.J., Jr.|last2=Skotland|first2=C.B.|title=Common Names of Diseases {{!}} Diseases of Mint|url=http://www.apsnet.org/publications/commonnames/Pages/Mint.aspx|publisher=The American Phytopathological Society|accessdate=2018-01-06|date=23 March 1993}} [[Category:Lists of plant diseases|Mint]] [[Category:Gardening lists]] [[Category:Mint diseases| ]]

This is a '''list of oil pipelines'''.
==Africa== * [[Chad–Cameroon Petroleum Development and Pipeline Project|Chad–Cameroon pipeline]] – [[Chad]]–[[Cameroon]] * Sudeth pipeline – [[South Sudan]]–[[Ethiopia]] (under construction) * [[Transnet Pipelines]] – [[South Africa]] * [[Sumed pipeline]] – [[Egypt]] * [[Tazama Pipeline]] – [[Tanzania]]– [[Zambia]] * [[Nembe Creek Trunk Line]] – [[Nigeria]]
==Asia== * [[Afghanistan Oil Pipeline]] (planned) * [[Alashankou–Dushanzi Crude Oil Pipeline]] * [[Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline]] * [[Baku–Supsa Pipeline]] * [[Baku–Novorossiysk pipeline]] * [[Caspian Pipeline Consortium]] * [[Eastern Siberia–Pacific Ocean oil pipeline]] * [[Habshan–Fujairah oil pipeline]] * [[Kabrai–Dhanbad cutter pipeline]] * [[Kandla–Gorakhpur LPG pipeline]] (planned) * [[Kazakhstan–China oil pipeline]] * [[Kirkuk–Banias pipeline]] * [[Kirkuk–Ceyhan Oil Pipeline]] * [https://www.iocl.com/aboutus/PipelineNetworknew.html Koyali–Mohanpura product pipeline] * [[Mumbai–Manmad Pipeline]] * [[Mundra–Delhi pipeline]] * [https://www.iocl.com/aboutus/PipelineNetworknew.html Mundra–Panipat crude oil pipeline] * [https://www.iocl.com/aboutus/PipelineNetworknew.html Paradip-Haldia-Barauni crude oil pipeline] * PS Pipeline<ref>http://www.petronas.com.my/about-us/petronas-directory/Pages/PETRONAS%20Directory/PS-Pipeline-Sdn-Bhd.aspx</ref> * [[Samsun–Ceyhan Pipeline]] * [[Sino-Burma pipelines]] * [[South–North Pipeline Korea]] * [[Trans-Arabian Pipeline]], a.k.a. Tapline (defunct) * [[Trans-Israel pipeline]] * [[Trans Korea Pipeline]] * [[Trans-Caspian Oil Pipeline]] – planned * [https://www.iocl.com/aboutus/PipelineNetworknew.html Salaya–Mathura crude oil pipeline] * [[White Oil Pipeline]] in [[Pakistan]]
==Europe== [[File:Oil pipelines in Europe.png|thumb|right|300px|Oil pipelines in Europe (2007)]]
* [[Adria oil pipeline]] * [[AMBO pipeline]] * [[Baltic Pipeline System]] * [[Brent System]] * [[Burgas-Alexandroupoli pipeline]] * [[CLH Pipelines]] – Spain * [[Druzhba pipeline]] * [[Forties pipeline system]] * [[Grozny-Tuapse oil pipeline|Grozny-Tuapse pipeline]] * [[Ninian pipeline]] * [[Odessa-Brody pipeline]] * [[Pan-European Pipeline]] * [[Transalpine Pipeline]] * [[South European Pipeline]] * [[TRAPIL]] – France
==North America== {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" |+TCanada !Name !Status !Capacity (bpd) !Receipt Point(s) !Crossing !Delivery Point(s) !Owner(s) !Length (km) !Regulator !Notes |- |Aurora |operating |45,000 |Rangeland Pipeline |Carway |Glacier Pipeline |Plains Midstream |0.75 |AER | |- |Cochin |operating | |Explorer, TEPPCO, Wabash pipelines at Kankakee, IL |Elmore, SK |Fort Saskatchewan, AB | | | |Moves condensate westward from 2014; from 1979 it moved product eastward. |- |Enbridge Bakken |operating |145,000 |Steelman, SK, & Berthold, ND |Portal |Enbridge Mainline at Cromer |Enbridge Bakken Pipeline Co |132 | | |- |[[Enbridge Pipeline System]] |operating | |Kerrobert & Regina, SK; Cromer, MB; Clearbrook, MB |Gretna, MB | |Enbridge | | | |- |Enbridge Norman Wells |suspended | |Norman Well, NWT | |Zama, AB |Enbridge Pipelines (NW) Inc. |869 c | |Shut down after 2016 |- |Express Pipeline |operating |280,000 |Hardisty, AB |Wild Horse, AB |Casper, WY |Express Pipeline Ltd |439 c | | |- |[[Keystone Pipeline]] 1 |operating |300,000 |Alberta (Hardisty) |Haskett, AB |Steele City, NB & Cushing, OK |TransCanada | | |Crosses South Dakota to Steele City, where it branches east through Kansas and Missouri to delivery points at Wood River and Patoka, Illinois, and south to delivery points at Cushing, Oklahoma and Houston and Port Arthur, Texas. Along the way at Patoka, Keystone delivers crude oil to the Plains terminal which facilitates delivery to local refineries via third party pipelines. |- |Keystone Pipeline 2 |operating | | | | | | | | |- |[[Keystone XL Pipeline]] |proposed | | | | |TransCanada | | | |- |Milk River Pipeline |operating |97,900 |Bow River Pipeline, Milk River, AB |Sweetgrass, MT |Front Range Pipeline, Coutts, AB |Plains Midstream |69 c |AER | |- |[[Portland-Montreal Pipe Line]] |part operation |223,000 |South Portland, ME | |Montreal, QC |Montreal Pipe Line Ltd |236 c | |This is the NEB-regulated segment of the Portland-Montreal pipeline system. Moves crude from Atlantic to Suncor refinery at Montreal. Two of 3 pipelines decommissioned (12 & 18 inch). Only 24-inch in operation |- |Southern Lights |operating |180,000 |Manhattan, IL | |Edmonton, AB |Enbridge Southern Lights GP Inc. |1529 c | |Moves diluent north; formed in 2010 by reversing 1465 km of former Enbridge Line 13 and constructing 1091 km of new pipeline in the U.S. It shares the Enbridge Mainline right-of-way. |- |[[Trans Mountain Pipeline System]] |operating | |Edmonton, AB, & Kamloops, BC. | |Burnaby & Burrard Inlet, BC, & Sumas, WA |Kinder Morgan | | |Moves crude oil & petroleum products to Parkland Burnaby refinery & Suncor Burrard products terminal; moves crude oil to four refineries in Washington via connection at Sumas to Puget Sound Pipeline; moves crude oil to Asia and U.S. West coast via Westridge Marine Terminal in Burnaby. One of few to ship crude & products in one pipe |- |Trans-Northern |operating |132,000 |Montreal & Nanticoke | |Toronto, Oakville, Ottawa, Maitland, Belleville, Cornwall, Kingston, Montreal, Dorval | | | |RPPs delivery at points including Oakville, Toronto, Ottawa, Maitland, Belleville, Cornwall, Kingston, Montreal, Dorval; operates bi-directionally between Toronto & Oakville. Three other petroleum products pipelines (two Sun-Canadian and Enbridge’s Line 8) transport gasoline, diesel, heating oil and jet fuel to Toronto and other cities along the route. |- |Utopia / Cochin Eastern |operating |50,000 |Harrison County, OH | |Windsor, ON | | | |Formerly the eastern part of Cochin. Moves ethane from new pipeline from a point in Harrison County to a connection with existing Kinder Morgan pipeline and facilities near Riga, Michigan. |- |Wascana |operating |40,000 |Raymond Station, MT | |Plains Terminal, Regina |Plains Midstream |173 c | |Moves light crude from Bakken north to connect to Enbridge Mainline at Regina; prior to 2012 it was southbound |- |Westspur |operating |247,400 |Alida, Steelman, Bryant, Midale, SK | |Enbridge Mainline near Cromer, MB |TEML |511 c |Saskatchewan |Tundra Energy Marketing; Moves crude oil & condensate to Mainline; until Dec. 2106 owned by Enbridge |}
=== Enbridge Pipelines (NW) Inc.United States ===
* [[Big Inch]] * [[Calnev Pipeline]] * [[Chaparral NGL System]] * [[Colonial Pipeline]] * [[Dakota Access Pipeline]] * [[Dixie Pipeline]] * [[Double H Pipeline]] * [[Dow Pipeline Company]] * [[Enbridge Pipeline System]] * [http://www.jayhawkpl.com/ Jayhawk and Kaw Pipelines] * [[Keystone Pipeline]] * [[Keystone XL Pipeline]] (proposed) * [[Lakehead Pipeline]] * [[Longhorn Pipeline]] * [[Magellan Midstream Partners]] * [[Mid-America Pipeline System]] * [[Minnesota Pipeline]] * [[North Dakota Pipeline Company system|North Dakota Pipeline]] * [[Olympic Pipeline]] * [[Plantation Pipeline]] * [[Pilgrim Pipeline]] (proposed) * [[Pony Express Pipeline]] * [[Ruby Pipeline]] * [[Seaway Pipeline]] * [[Seminole Pipeline]] * [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] * [[Trans Mountain Pipeline]] * [[Unev Pipeline]] * [[Yellowstone Pipeline]]
===Other pipelines=== * Sand Hills Pipeline: This pipeline is being developed by [[DCP Midstream Partners | DCP Midstream]]. It will extend for 700 miles from West to East Texas and have an initial capacity of approximately 120,000 barrels per day.<ref name="pipelineandgasjournal.com">[http://www.pipelineandgasjournal.com/2012-worldwide-pipeline-construction-report "2012 Worldwide Pipeline Construction Report]," ''Pipeline and Gas Journal'' '''239''' (1). January 2012.</ref> The first segment of the pipeline opened in October 2012.<ref>[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20121024006533/en/DCP-Midstream-Announces-Opening-Sand-Hills-Pipeline "DCP Midstream Announces Opening of Sand Hills Pipeline Providing NGL Access from the Eagle Ford Shale]," October 24, 2012, Business Wire.</ref> * Pecos River Pipeline: Developed by Bridger Group and Advantage Pipeline, the Pecos River Pipeline will provide a link from the [[Delaware Basin]] to the Gulf Coast. The pipeline will run from the [[Pecos, Texas]], to [[Crane, Texas]], where it will connect to the Longhorn Pipeline. The Pecos River Pipeline will have an initial capacity of 150,000 barrels per day.<ref>[http://www.pipelineandgasjournal.com/bridger-joins-advantage-pipeline-development-pecos-river-project "Bridger Joins Advantage Pipeline in Development of Pecos River Pipeline]," ''Pipeline and Gas Journal'' '''239''' (11). November 2012.</ref> * Sterling III Pipeline: Under development from [[ONEOK|Oneok Partners]], the Sterling III Pipeline will extend from parts of Texas and Oklahoma in the [[Mid-continent Oil Field|Mid-Continent region]] to the Gulf Coast, and have a capacity of approximately 193,000 barrels per day.<ref>Walton, Rod. [http://www.tulsaworld.com/business/article.aspx?subjectid=49&articleid=20110503_49_E1_ONEOKP776284 "ONEOK plans new pipeline]," May 3, 2011, ''The Tulsa World''.</ref> * ATEX Express: [[Enterprise Products Partners]] is developing the 1,230-mile ATEX Express pipeline to transport [[ethane]] from Pennsylvania, West Virginia, and Ohio to the Gulf Coast.<ref>Zacks Equity Research. [https://finance.yahoo.com/news/epds-atex-express-offers-capacity-124433077.html "EPD's ATEX Express Offers Capacity]," August 31, 2012, Yahoo! Finance.</ref>
==Ibero America== * [[Activo de Burgos pipeline network]] – Mexico * [[Burgos–Monterrey pipeline]] – Mexico * [[Cadereyta pipeline]] – Mexico * [[Ecopetrol pipelines]] – Colombia * [[OCP pipeline]] – Ecuador * [[Oil tanking pipeline]] – Argentina * [[PDVSA pipelines]] – Venezuela * [[PEMEX pipelines]] – Mexico * [[Petroandina pipeline]] – Argentina (Under Construction) * [[Recope pipelines]] – Costa Rica * [[San Fernando pipeline]] – Mexico * [[SOTE pipeline]] – Ecuador * [[Tamazunchale pipeline]] – Mexico * [[TGN pipeline network]] – Argentina * [[TGI pipeline network]] – Colombia * [[TGS pipeline network]] – Argentina * [[Trans-Isthmian pipeline]] – Panama * [[Transpetro]] pipelines – Brazil
==See also== * [[List of oil refineries]] * [[List of natural gas pipelines]] * [[Pipeline transport]]

revision.comment: /* Dead Sea */ split into those rivers flowing into the Jordan and those directly into the Dead Sea
revision.text:
This is a '''list of rivers in [[Jordan]]'''. This list is arranged by drainage basin, with respective tributaries indented under each larger stream's name. Many of these rivers are seasonal.
==[[Dead Sea]]==
=== Jordan River ===
The [[Jordan River]] is the major river flowing into the Dead Sea from the north. It also is the northern part of the western border of Jordan. From south to north the rivers flowing into it are: *[[Wadi al Gharabah]] **[[Wadi al Kafrayn]] ***[[Valley of the Orchads, Ammān|Wadi as Seer]] **[[Wadi ar Ramah]] *[[Wadi Shu'ayb]] (Wadi Sha'eb) *[[Zarqa River]] (Jabbok River) - second largest tributary of the Jordan, flows in about half way between the [[Sea of Galilee]] and the Dead Sea **[[Wadi Zulayl]] (Wadi Dhuleil) *[[Wadi Kufrinjah]] *[[Wadi Yabes]] *[[Wadi Ziqlab]] *[[Wadi al 'Arab]] *[[Yarmouk River]] - largest tributary of the Jordan and forms part of the northern boundary of Jordan. Flows into the Jordan just south of the Sea of Galilee === Other rivers === Other rivers that flow directly into the Dead Sea are: *[[Wadi Zarqa' Ma'in]] *[[Wadi Mujib]] (Arnon) **[[Wadi al Haydan]] **[[Wadi an Nukhaylah]] **[[Wadi al Hafirah]] *[[Wadi ash Shuqayq]] *[[Wadi al Karak]] *[[Arabah|Wadi Arabah]] (Wadi al-Jayb) - the valley to the south of the Dead Sea and also a western boundary of Jordan. **[[Wadi Zered]] also known as Wadi al Hasa. **[[Wadi al Fidan]] **[[Wadi al Buwayridah]] **[[Wadi Musa]]
==[[Red Sea]] ([[Gulf of Aqaba]])==
*[[Wadi Yitm]] **[[Wadi Rum]]
==[[Syrian Desert]]==
*[[Wadi as Sirhan]] **Far Wadi al Abyad **Wadi Fakk Abu Thiran **Wadi al Fukuk **Wadi el Hasah **Wadi al Gharra **[[Wadi Ba'ir]] **[[Wadi al Makhruq]] **Wadi al Jashshah al Adlah **Wadi Rijlat **Wadi al Ghadaf **Wadi al Janab
===Qa Al Jafr=== *Wadi Abu Safah **Wadi al Buraykah *Wadi Abu Tarafah *Wadi Abu 'Amud *Wadi al Jahdaniyah *Wadi Kabid *Wadi al 'Unab
==References== *Rand McNally, ''The New International Atlas'', 1993. *[http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/index.html GEOnet Names Server]
{{Asia topic|List of rivers of}}
[[Category:Rivers of Jordan|*]] [[Category:Lists of rivers by country|Jordan]] [[Category:Lists of landforms of Jordan|Rivers]]

page.title: List of rivers of the Bahamas

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Deep Creek]] (link changed to [[Deep Creek (Bahamas)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
There are no rivers in the Bahamas. In March 2018 waves breaking over cliffs near the Glass Window Bridge in Eleuthera caused a flow of water across the island that washed out the Queens Highway, and was temporarily called a new river. There are also many [[creek (tidal)|tidal creeks]], which resemble rivers.
This is a '''list of creeks in [[The Bahamas]]'''.
==[[Andros Island]]==
*[[Staniard Creek]] *[[Sandy Creek (Bahamas)|Sandy Creek]] *[[Fresh Creek]] *[[Somerset Creek]] *[[Cargill Creek]] *[[Lisbon Creek]] *[[Grassy Creek (Bahamas)|Grassy Creek]] *[[Little Grassy Creek]] *[[Goose River (Bahamas)|Goose River]] *[[River Lees]] *[[Pelican Creek]] *[[Hawk Creek (Bahamas)|Hawk Creek]] *[[Sapodilla Creek]] *[[Mount Creek]] *[[Timber Creek (Bahamas)|Timber Creek]] *[[Deep Creek (Bahamas)|Deep Creek]] *[[Simon Creek]] *[[Loggerhead Creek]]
==[[Eleuthera Island]]==
*[[Deep Creek (Bahamas)|Deep Creek]] *[[Starve Creek]]
